transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I see from your chart that you are a 66-year-old woman with a significant past medical history of well-controlled hypertension. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've had complaints of microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria for the past 3 years.
Doctor: I see. How has your creatinine level been during this time?
Patient: It was within normal range when it was last checked.
Doctor: Alright. I noticed that we performed a renal biopsy on you. The results showed mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis with fibro-cellular crescents in one out of 18 glomeruli, excluding one global sclerotic glomerulus. The immunofluorescence microscopy revealed the deposition of IgA and C3 in mesangial areas. There was also weak but significant IgG deposition in the glomeruli, somewhat different from the distribution of IgA or C3. Electron microscopy confirmed the presence of electron-dense deposits in mesangial areas. Based on these findings, you were diagnosed with IgA nephropathy.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: To manage your condition, you were started on antihypertensive therapy, mainly with an RAS inhibitor. However, eight months later, your serum creatinine suddenly rose to 4.53 mg/dL from 1.04 mg/dL a month before. Urinalysis showed 100 red blood cells per high power field and urinary protein excretion of 12.3 g/gCr. We then conducted serological tests to differentiate the cause of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The tests revealed the presence of anti-GBM antibody at a titer of 116 IU/mL and the absence of anti-nuclear antibody and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: After your admission, we initiated treatments with hemodialysis, plasma exchange, and intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy followed by oral prednisolone at a dose of 50 mg/day. We performed a second renal biopsy at four weeks after admission to assess the probability of renal recovery and make a final diagnosis. The biopsy revealed cellular to fibrocellular crescents in 18 of 25 glomeruli, excluding six global sclerotic glomeruli. The immunofluorescence study showed linear IgG deposition along the glomerular capillary walls and mesangial staining for IgA.
Patient: What does that mean for my condition?
Doctor: The results of the second biopsy, along with your clinical history and lab findings, confirm the diagnosis of IgA nephropathy with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. We will continue to monitor your condition closely and adjust your treatments as needed to ensure the best possible outcome.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help in managing my condition.
Doctor: You're welcome. It's important to stay on top of your treatment and follow-up appointments. If you have any concerns or symptoms, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We're here to help you.
Patient: Thank you, I will.

gold_soap.S: 66-year-old female with a history of well-controlled hypertension presents with complaints of microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria for the past 3 years. She reports that her creatinine levels were within normal range until eight months ago when it suddenly increased.
gold_soap.O: Last creatinine level was 4.53 mg/dL, up from 1.04 mg/dL a month prior. Urinalysis revealed 100 red blood cells per high power field and urinary protein excretion of 12.3 g/gCr. Initial renal biopsy indicated mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis with fibro-cellular crescents and deposition of IgA, C3, and IgG. Electron microscopy confirmed electron-dense deposits in mesangial areas. Serological tests showed anti-GBM antibody at a titer of 116 IU/mL. A second renal biopsy showed cellular to fibrocellular crescents in 18 of 25 glomeruli with linear IgG deposition along the glomerular capillary walls.
gold_soap.A: Diagnosis of IgA nephropathy with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The patient's condition has evolved from initial IgA nephropathy to include features of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, evidenced by worsening renal function and biopsy findings.
gold_soap.P: Continue current regimen of hemodialysis, plasma exchange, and corticosteroid therapy (intravenous methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisolone 50 mg/day). Monitor renal function and adjust treatments as necessary. Emphasize the importance of adherence to treatment and regular follow-up appointments to assess response to therapy and modify management plan accordingly.

ai_soap.S: 66-year-old woman with well-controlled hypertension presenting with a 3-year history of microscopic hematuria and mild proteinuria; subsequently developed rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with acute rise in serum creatinine to 4.53 mg/dL.
ai_soap.O: Initial renal biopsy showed mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis with fibro-cellular crescents (1/18 glomeruli) and IgA/C3 deposition; second biopsy at 4 weeks revealed cellular to fibrocellular crescents (18/25 glomeruli) with linear IgG deposition along glomerular capillary walls and mesangial IgA staining. Serological tests positive for anti-GBM antibody (116 IU/mL), negative for ANCA and ANA; urinalysis showed 100 RBC/hpf with proteinuria of 12.3 g/gCr.
ai_soap.A: IgA nephropathy with rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and anti-GBM disease, manifesting as acute kidney injury with creatinine rise from 1.04 to 4.53 mg/dL over one month.
ai_soap.P: Hemodialysis, plasma exchange, and intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy initiated followed by oral prednisolone 50 mg/day; continue close monitoring and adjust treatments as needed with regular follow-up appointments and patient communication regarding symptoms or concerns.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have a history of anxiety, depression, and anorexia nervosa. Can you tell me about your symptoms and how long you've been experiencing them?
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really sad, lonely, and hopeless. I also can't enjoy things I used to like. I've been restricting my eating to lose weight for a few years now.
Doctor: I see. You were admitted to our hospital twice, the first one in September 2019 when you lost 16 kg over 3-4 months and were weighing 40 kg with a BMI of 16.0 kg/m2. You also had sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 30-40 BPM. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: According to your lab values during your two admissions, there were significant changes. Now, regarding your eating habits, have you ever engaged in purging, bingeing, or using laxatives?
Patient: No, I haven't done any of those things.
Doctor: I understand you have been emaciated and minimized the severity of your nutritional status and preoccupation with your weight and body image. Have you ever had any suicidal thoughts or desired death?
Patient: I don't really think about suicide, but sometimes I wish I could die rather than deal with my eating disorder.
Doctor: It's important to address these feelings and work towards recovery. I see that you have experienced several moves during your childhood, and you reported increased anxiety after a recent move due to your parents' divorce and starting a new school. Is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, that's true. It's been really tough.
Doctor: You have received eating disorder treatment at various levels of care, including inpatient, residential, partial hospitalization, and intensive outpatient programs in four states. Is that right?
Patient: Yes, I've been through a lot of treatment programs.
Doctor: It seems that at times, you've become physically aggressive towards staff and family, and in one instance, you bit a chunk off the nape of your sister's neck during a family visit at a residential stay. This led to your discharge. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, I got really jealous of my sister because she was going home after the visit, and I had to stay. I just lost control.
Doctor: It's important to address these behaviors as well. For now, we will place you on 1:1 for safety concerns. We will work together to create a treatment plan tailored to your needs and support you on your journey to recovery.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

gold_soap.S: The patient reports long-standing feelings of sadness, loneliness, and hopelessness, with a loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities. The patient has a history of restricting food intake to lose weight, ongoing for several years, without engaging in purging, bingeing, or using laxatives. The patient denies active suicidal ideation but expresses a wish to die to escape the burden of the eating disorder. The patient has experienced increased anxiety following parental divorce and a recent move. There is a history of physical aggression, including a severe incident involving a family member during a treatment program.
gold_soap.O: The patient has a history of two hospital admissions, with significant weight loss (16 kg over 3-4 months) leading to a BMI of 16.0 kg/m2 and sinus bradycardia (heart rate 30-40 BPM). The patient has been treated in various settings for an eating disorder, including inpatient, residential, partial hospitalization, and intensive outpatient programs across four states.
gold_soap.A: The primary diagnosis is anorexia nervosa, with comorbid major depressive disorder and anxiety. The patient's history of physical aggression and severe restriction of food intake complicates the treatment. The prognosis is guarded due to the chronic nature of the eating disorder and psychiatric comorbidities.
gold_soap.P: The immediate plan includes placing the patient on 1:1 monitoring due to safety concerns. A comprehensive treatment plan will be developed, focusing on nutritional rehabilitation, psychotherapy for depression and anxiety, and strategies to manage aggressive behaviors. Continued psychiatric evaluation and close monitoring of vital signs and nutritional status are necessary. Referral to a specialist in eating disorders for ongoing management and possible reevaluation of the current treatment strategy is recommended. Education about the illness and its management will be provided to the patient and family to improve compliance and understanding.

ai_soap.S: Patient reports persistent sadness, loneliness, hopelessness, and anhedonia for several years with concurrent restrictive eating to lose weight over the same period. Patient denies suicidal ideation but expresses passive death wishes to escape her eating disorder; she also reports increased anxiety following parental divorce, multiple childhood moves, and starting a new school.
ai_soap.O: History of two psychiatric hospitalizations; first admission September 2019 with 16 kg weight loss over 3-4 months, final weight 40 kg, BMI 16.0 kg/m², and sinus bradycardia (HR 30-40 BPM). Patient denies purging, bingeing, or laxative use. History of physical aggression toward staff and family, including biting sister during residential treatment, leading to discharge. Extensive treatment history across four states including inpatient, residential, partial hospitalization, and intensive outpatient programs.
ai_soap.A: Anorexia nervosa (restrictive type) with significant medical complications including bradycardia and severe weight loss; comorbid major depressive disorder; anxiety disorder; history of aggressive behavior with impulse control difficulties.
ai_soap.P: Admit to inpatient psychiatric unit with 1:1 supervision for safety monitoring; develop comprehensive treatment plan addressing eating disorder, mood symptoms, and behavioral concerns; coordinate multidisciplinary treatment across psychiatric, medical, and nutritional services; provide therapeutic support for trauma and adjustment issues related to family stressors.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I have a problem with my left eye. I suddenly got a large scotoma about a week ago.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent medical treatments or vaccinations?
Patient: Yes, I had the third intramuscular administration of a rabies vaccine seven days ago. It was from Novartis and called Rabipur. I got it because a stray cat scratched me.
Doctor: I understand. This rabies vaccine you received is an embryonated-egg vaccine. Have you received any other vaccines recently?
Patient: No, this was the only one. And it was the first time I had any symptoms after vaccination.
Doctor: Okay. Was the stray cat available for observation of rabies symptoms?
Patient: No, the cat wasn't available for observation.
Doctor: Alright. Do you have any remarkable medical history or underlying pathology?
Patient: No, I am otherwise healthy.
Doctor: So your best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes with − 9.0 D in the right eye and − 8.5 D in the left eye. We've also done an ophthalmoscopic examination of your left eye, and it revealed nothing that could explain your complaints. However, during the follow-up, you developed photopsia in the left eye. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: We also conducted visual field testing, which showed an enlarged blind spot and decreased sensitivity superiorly and nasally. Fundus fluorescence angiography (FFA) and autofluorescence (AF) revealed hyperfluorescence corresponding to the area of the retina in the region of ellipsoid zone abnormalities. FFA showed normal appearances in the arteriovenous and late phases in your right eye. However, early choroidal background hyperfluorescence and mild diffuse leakage of fluorescein were noted in the late phase of your left eye. Are you following so far?
Patient: Yes, I'm trying to understand.
Doctor: In addition, optical coherence tomography (OCT) demonstrated disruptions in the ellipsoid zone of the posterior retina. Fundus AF also showed multiple ill-defined spots of markedly increased AF in the posterior pole.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We have also done a complete blood cell count, immunological test, syphilis, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) tests, which all came back normal. We will continue to monitor your condition and determine the best course of action for your eye issue. In the meantime, if you experience any changes or worsening of your symptoms, please contact us immediately.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

gold_soap.S: The patient, a previously healthy individual, reports a sudden onset of a large scotoma in the left eye occurring one week ago. The patient recently received the third dose of the Rabipur rabies vaccine following a scratch from a stray cat. No other recent vaccinations or significant medical history were reported. The patient also developed photopsia in the left eye.
gold_soap.O: The patient's best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes with prescriptions of −9.0 D in the right eye and −8.5 D in the left eye. Ophthalmoscopic examination of the left eye showed no abnormalities. Visual field testing indicated an enlarged blind spot with decreased sensitivity superiorly and nasally in the left eye. Fundus fluorescence angiography and autofluorescence revealed hyperfluorescence and ellipsoid zone abnormalities in the left eye, with normal findings in the right eye. Optical coherence tomography showed disruptions in the ellipsoid zone of the posterior retina in the left eye. Complete blood cell count, immunological tests, and screenings for syphilis and HIV were normal.
gold_soap.A: The primary diagnosis is a post-vaccination ocular complication, specifically involving the left eye with ellipsoid zone disruptions and photopsia. Differential diagnoses could include autoimmune retinopathy or other inflammatory conditions, though the lack of systemic symptoms and normal immunological tests make these less likely.
gold_soap.P: The management plan includes close monitoring of the patient's ocular condition with follow-up appointments scheduled to reassess the visual and structural changes in the left eye. The patient is advised to immediately report any new symptoms or worsening of the current condition. Education regarding the potential ocular side effects of vaccinations will be provided to ensure the patient is informed about their condition and the importance of follow-up. Referral to a specialist in retinal disorders may be considered if there is no improvement or further deterioration in the patient's condition.

ai_soap.S: Patient presents with sudden onset of large scotoma in left eye occurring one week after receiving third intramuscular dose of embryonated-egg rabies vaccine (Rabipur) following a stray cat scratch; during follow-up, patient developed photopsia in the left eye.
ai_soap.O: Best-corrected visual acuity 20/20 in both eyes (−9.0 D right eye, −8.5 D left eye); visual field testing shows enlarged blind spot and decreased sensitivity superiorly and nasally in left eye; OCT demonstrates disruptions in ellipsoid zone of posterior retina; fundus autofluorescence shows multiple ill-defined spots of markedly increased AF in posterior pole; FFA reveals early choroidal background hyperfluorescence and mild diffuse leakage of fluorescein in late phase of left eye; ophthalmoscopic examination unremarkable; complete blood cell count, immunological tests, syphilis, and HIV tests all normal.
ai_soap.A: Suspected vaccine-associated retinal toxicity following rabies vaccination (Rabipur), likely acute maculopathy with ellipsoid zone disruption and associated scotoma and photopsia; infectious and immunological causes ruled out.
ai_soap.P: Continue monitoring of left eye condition; patient advised to report immediately any changes or worsening of symptoms; follow-up evaluation to determine best course of treatment for eye pathology.

transcript:
Doctor: Hello, I am aware that you have a history of schizoaffective disorder, chronic renal failure, type 2 diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, previous stroke with a right arm contracture, and aortic stenosis. You are currently on risperidone and escitalopram, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: You were admitted in December 2015 due to a urinary tract infection, acute renal failure, and deranged international normalized ratio (INR). The Psychiatry service was consulted shortly after your admission. Can you tell me more about your mood during that time?
Patient: Well, my mood was quite low since my brother fell ill about 2 months before that. My antidepressant dose was increased a month before my admission.
Doctor: I see. So at that time, you were at your baseline mental state, engaging well in conversation and denying any low mood, which was confirmed by the community mental health nurse. No changes were made to your management, right?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: A week later, the neurology service was asked to review you due to an altered level of consciousness. During the examination, you presented with waxy flexibility, negativism, new onset increased tone of your left arm, posturing, and catalepsy. Your mobility had deteriorated, with selective speech, mute episodes, and poor oral intake noted by medical staff. Does that sound accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's exactly what happened.
Doctor: The impression was that you were suffering from acute catatonia. An MRI of your brain was performed, and it showed no acute changes. Nasogastric (NG) feeding was established to ensure adequate oral intake. The psychiatry service was again consulted, and they confirmed the diagnosis of acute catatonia. You were diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder with catatonia, as per DSM-5. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: A trial of lorazepam was advised for the treatment of catatonia. The dose was titrated to 3 mg per day. How did you respond to the treatment?
Patient: The treatment worked well for me.
Doctor: That's great to hear. It's important to continue monitoring your symptoms and maintain communication with your healthcare team. If you notice any changes in your mood or experience any new symptoms, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and advice.

gold_soap.S: The patient, with a history of schizoaffective disorder, chronic renal failure, type 2 diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, previous stroke with right arm contracture, and aortic stenosis, reported a low mood related to his brother's illness two months prior to his last hospital admission in December 2015. During that admission, his mood was stable, and no changes were made to his psychiatric management. However, he later developed symptoms of acute catatonia including waxy flexibility, negativism, increased tone in the left arm, posturing, and catalepsy, along with deteriorated mobility, selective speech, mute episodes, and poor oral intake.
gold_soap.O: On physical examination, the patient showed signs of acute catatonia. An MRI of the brain showed no acute changes. The patient was on risperidone and escitalopram, and a trial of lorazepam up to 3 mg per day was initiated, which he responded well to. His vital signs and other specific lab results like INR were not provided in the dialogue.
gold_soap.A: The primary diagnosis is schizoaffective disorder with acute catatonia. Differential diagnoses could include other causes of altered mental status such as metabolic encephalopathy or neuroleptic malignant syndrome, considering the patient's complex medical history and medication regimen.
gold_soap.P: Continue monitoring the patient's response to lorazepam for catatonia. Maintain risperidone and escitalopram for underlying schizoaffective disorder. Regular follow-up with psychiatry to monitor mental status and adjust medications as needed. Encourage the patient to maintain communication with the healthcare team, especially if new symptoms arise or mood changes. Nutritional support through established NG feeding should be assessed and continued as necessary. Further consultations with neurology and nephrology should be considered to manage his chronic conditions and prevent complications.

ai_soap.S: Patient with long-standing history of schizoaffective disorder, chronic renal failure, type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, previous stroke with right arm contracture, and aortic stenosis presents with mood described as "quite low" following brother's illness 2 months prior; antidepressant dose increased 1 month before admission in December 2015.
ai_soap.O: Admitted December 2015 with urinary tract infection, acute renal failure, and deranged INR; presented with waxy flexibility, negativism, new onset increased tone of left arm, posturing, catalepsy, deteriorated mobility, selective speech, mute episodes, and poor oral intake; brain MRI showed no acute changes; currently on risperidone and escitalopram.
ai_soap.A: Acute catatonia secondary to schizoaffective disorder, diagnosed per DSM-5; no acute structural brain pathology identified on MRI.
ai_soap.P: Initiated lorazepam trial titrated to 3 mg daily for treatment of catatonia with good clinical response; nasogastric feeding established for adequate nutritional intake; continue monitoring symptoms and maintain communication with healthcare team; advise patient to report any changes in mood or new symptoms.

transcript:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you have a complex medical history, including a total hip arthroplasty, bladder carcinoma in situ, and chronic kidney disease. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing worsening pain in my left thigh lately.
Doctor: I see. You had a THA placed thirty-one years ago, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And you also had a papillary bladder tumor that was treated with fulguration five years prior to admission, followed by a recurrence of bladder carcinoma in situ diagnosed a year later, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I underwent six initial and six maintenance instillations of Bacillus Calmette-Guérin treatment, which is a strain of Mycobacterium bovis, and my bladder cancer went into remission.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. Now, tell me more about this new pain in your left thigh.
Patient: Well, about four years after the BCG therapy, I developed new-onset drainage from my left lateral thigh. It started swelling and I've been having increasing purulent discharge, pain with movement, chills, rigors, and a fever of 101 °F.
Doctor: How are you feeling today? Are you still experiencing fever?
Patient: I'm afebrile now and my vital signs are normal.
Doctor: Good to know. Let me examine your thigh. Hmm, there's an open wound on the lateral left thigh with purulent drainage and surrounding erythema. Does it hurt when I adduct your left hip?
Patient: Yes, it's painful.
Doctor: I'd like to order some laboratory tests. Your white blood cell count is 10,200 cells/mm3, C-reactive protein is 9.7 mg/dL, and sedimentation rate is 71 mm/hr. We also took a radiograph of your left hip, which showed extensive lucencies around the left THA.
Patient: What does that mean, Doctor?
Doctor: It means we need to take further action. You underwent incision and drainage with an antibiotic spacer placed following admission. Wound, hip fluid, and abscess cultures obtained during irrigation and debridement were negative for bacterial pathogens. However, given your history of prior BCG therapy, we asked the microbiology laboratory to perform mycobacterial cultures, which grew acid-fast bacilli concerning for Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex.
Patient: Oh, no. What's the next step?
Doctor: We initially treated you with clindamycin, ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and metronidazole. Now, you'll be started on isoniazid 300 mg PO daily and rifampin for your tuberculosis complex. We'll closely monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I hope this will help me get better soon.

gold_soap.S: The patient, with a history of total hip arthroplasty (THA), bladder carcinoma in situ treated with Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG), and chronic kidney disease, presents with worsening pain in the left thigh, new-onset drainage, swelling, purulent discharge, pain with movement, chills, rigors, and a previous fever of 101 °F. The patient reports the pain started approximately four years after BCG therapy. Currently, the patient is afebrile with normal vital signs.
gold_soap.O: Physical examination reveals an open wound on the lateral left thigh with purulent drainage and surrounding erythema, painful on adduction of the left hip. Laboratory tests show a white blood cell count of 10,200 cells/mm3, C-reactive protein at 9.7 mg/dL, and sedimentation rate at 71 mm/hr. Radiograph of the left hip shows extensive lucencies around the THA. Mycobacterial cultures from the wound, hip fluid, and abscess grew acid-fast bacilli concerning for Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex.
gold_soap.A: The primary diagnosis is a Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex infection secondary to prior BCG therapy, complicated by a probable prosthetic joint infection given the symptoms and radiographic findings. Differential diagnoses include other bacterial joint infections, though cultures were negative.
gold_soap.P: The patient was initially treated with clindamycin, ceftriaxone, vancomycin, and metronidazole. Following the identification of Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex, the treatment plan was adjusted to include isoniazid 300 mg PO daily and rifampin. The patient will be closely monitored for response to therapy and potential side effects, with adjustments to the treatment plan as necessary. Further consultations with infectious disease specialists and orthopedic surgeons are planned to manage the joint infection and assess the need for surgical intervention.

ai_soap.S: Patient with 31-year-old total hip arthroplasty and history of bladder carcinoma in situ treated with BCG therapy now presenting with worsening left thigh pain, purulent drainage, swelling, fever (101°F), chills, and rigors that developed four years after BCG treatment; currently afebrile with normal vital signs.
ai_soap.O: Physical examination reveals open wound on lateral left thigh with purulent drainage and erythema; painful with left hip adduction. Labs: WBC 10,200 cells/mm³, CRP 9.7 mg/dL, ESR 71 mm/hr. Radiograph shows extensive lucencies around left THA. Mycobacterial cultures from wound, hip fluid, and abscess grew acid-fast bacilli concerning for Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex; bacterial cultures negative.
ai_soap.A: Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex infection of left hip prosthesis with surrounding soft tissue abscess and osteolytic changes, likely seeded from prior BCG therapy used for bladder cancer treatment.
ai_soap.P: Patient underwent incision and drainage with antibiotic spacer placement. Started on isoniazid 300 mg PO daily and rifampin for tuberculosis complex with close monitoring and plan to adjust treatment as needed.
